abstract.shortdesc: An abstract summarizes the content of the topic; it appears at the start of the topic. It can contain multiple short descriptions, as well as block-level content such as paragraphs, lists, and tables.

section.title: Usage information

div.p: The abstract element is designed for use in the following circumstances:

ul.li: The initial paragraph of a topic contains lists, tables, or other block-level elements that are not permitted in the content model of shortdesc.
Only a portion of the content of the initial paragraph is suitable for a link preview or hover text.
A topic needs to contain multiple short descriptions, to facilitate conditional processing.

section.p: When the initial paragraph is suitable as a link preview, simply place the content in a shortdesc element rather than in an abstract element.

section.title: Rendering expectations
section.p: When a contained shortdesc occurs within phrase-level content, processors treat it as phrase-level content and do not create a separate paragraph when the topic is rendered. When the contained shortdesc occurs as a peer to paragraph-level content, processors treat it as block-level content and create a separate paragraph when the topic is rendered. When multiple shortdesc elements are included in an abstract, they are concatenated when used for link previews or link summaries (separated by spaces).

example.title: Examples
example.p: This section contains examples of how the abstract element can be used.

fig.title: abstract with phrase-level short description
fig.p: The following code sample shows an abstract element that contains phrase-level content, in addition to a short description:
fig.codeblock: <abstract> <shortdesc>Use the wonderful Widget to automatically vacuum your house. </shortdesc> It requires a 1800 lithium ion battery. </abstract>
fig.p: While the complete content of the abstract element is rendered as the first paragraph of the topic, only the content of the shortdesc element is used for a link preview and hover text.

fig.title: abstract with block-level short description
fig.p: The following code sample shows an abstract element that contains block-level content, in addition to a short description:
fig.codeblock:
You have many options for arranging lodging in Brussels: hotels, bed and breakfasts, youth hostels, and flats. You can select from a wide price range.

The following table explains the symbols that are used to indicate the price categories of the lodging options:

fig.title: abstract with multiple short descriptions
fig.p: The following code sample shows an abstract element that contains multiple short descriptions, which will be filtered when the topic is processed:
fig.codeblock: <abstract> <shortdesc platform="free-version">The free version of the platform provides a single e-mail list, storage for up to one gigabyte of files, and will support up to 100 users.</shortdesc> <shortdesc platform="premium-version">The premium version of the platform provides multiple e-mails lists, storage for up to 30 gigabytes of files, and will support up to 400 users.</shortdesc> </abstract>
